article.description: Natalie Ritchie scored 18 of her 21 points in the first half, helping open up a 19-point halftime lead, and No. 7 Texas Tech cruised to an 80-58 win over Colorado.
article.headline: Colorado can't rebound from 19-point halftime hole
article.linkText: Texas Tech leads early to get past Colorado
article.story:
BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Natalie Ritchie didn't make every shot she
took. It only seemed that way from Colorado's vantage point.

	   Ritchie scored 18 of her 21 points in the first half, helping
open a 19-point halftime lead, and No. 7 Texas Tech cruised to an
80-58 victory over Colorado on Sunday.

	   "I thought in the first half Natalie Ritchie really, really
hurt us, way more than I expected her to hurt us,'' Colorado coach
Ceal Barry said. "Her outside shooting -- it was as if we couldn't
find her.''

	   Texas Tech coach Marsha Sharp agreed.

	   "Ritchie was a huge factor in the first half and was the
majority of our offense during that period of time,'' Sharp said.

	   Ritchie was 8-for-13 from the floor, including 5-for-9 from
3-point range. She played only the first six minutes of the second
half and sat out the rest of the game, the damage already having
been irreversible.

	   Texas Tech (16-2, 5-1 Big 12) also got 22 points and eight
rebounds from Plenette Pierson and 19 points from Jia Perkins.

	   "I think what is so great about our team is that we have so
many weapons offensively,'' Ritchie said. "We force other teams to
pick and choose who they're going to double. Today, it was nice to
get open and take some good shots.''

	   Tera Bjorklund had 26 points and 10 rebounds for Colorado (14-3,
4-2).

	   The Red Raiders, rebounding from Wednesday's 69-58 loss to No.
17 Texas, used a 16-1 run early in the game to build a 12-point
lead and never looked back. Tech shot 47 percent to Colorado's 38
percent and outrebounded the Buffaloes 44-37.

	   Ritchie hit four 3-pointers in the first half as the Red Raiders
bolted to a 45-26 lead.

	   Tech's early 16-1 run, which featured seven points from Perkins,
produced an 18-6 lead with 14:17 left in the half. Two of Perkins'
baskets came on layups after she stole the ball on the other end.

	   Pierson had two straight baskets to cap a 6-0 run for a 28-13
lead. Colorado countered with six straight points of its own,
capped by Bjorklund's layup, but the Red Raiders then ran off nine
straight points for a 37-19 lead. Ritchie started the flurry with a
3-pointer, and Cisti Greenwalt hit four free throws.

	   "We put ourselves in a hole right away,'' Colorado's Sabrina
Scott said, "and that's exactly what we didn't want to do against
a team like Texas Tech. They're a hard team to catch up against.
They took that big lead, and it was tough to get back into it.''

	   Ritchie hit consecutive 3-pointers in the final two minutes of
the half to give Texas Tech its biggest lead of the half, 45-24.

	   "We were a little bit surprised to be able to do that early,''
Sharp said. "We disrupted well defensively and turned that into
some opportunities on the offensive end. When we get that kind of
explosion out of Perkins and get that kind of shot production out
of Ritchie, our inside game usually has an easier time making
choices.''

	   Ritchie made another 3-pointer early in the second half, and
Pierson had three layups in the first five minutes as Tech pushed
its lead to 64-34.

	   Bjorklund scored 12 of Colorado's first 14 points in the half,
and she sparked a 10-1 flurry that cut the deficit to 65-46. But
the Buffs got no closer.

	   Bjorklund, a 6-foot-5 junior center, hit a layup with 12:30 left
for her 22nd point of the game, making her the 19th player in
Colorado history with 1,000 points.

	   "I really wasn't thinking about it,'' Bjorklund said. "It's
kind of exciting. It's a nice recognition. But I would have much
rather come out today with a win.''
